abstract: Mark V. Hurd was fired by the board at Hewlett-Packard, but the veracity of a racy lawsuit raises some questions about his ouster at a time when the company was thriving.
snippet: Mark V. Hurd was fired by the board at Hewlett-Packard, but the veracity of a racy lawsuit raises some questions about his ouster at a time when the company was thriving.
lead_paragraph: “Ms. Fisher was scared. She was a nervous wreck but attempted to appear relaxed. She sat down on one of two love seats in the sitting room. She was worried when you came over and sat directly next to her and put your arm on the back of the love seat. As you did so, your hand brushed across her breast. ... It happened a second time and Ms. Fisher said ‘you know that you are touching my breast, right?’ You said, ‘Oh, sorry, sorry’ and then laughed it off.”

headline.main: In H.P. Tale, a Question of Truth or Titillation
headline.print_headline: In H.P. Tale, A Question Of Truth Or Titillation
